DOC.HEAD: Contract Talks Break off at San Diego Newspapers
DOC.TEXT: Contract talks between The San Diego Union and The Tribune newspapers broke off after a strike deadline passed early today, but labor officials say they've decided against walking out at this time. Discussions ended after company lawyers rejected a proposal from the Newspaper Guild in which the union dropped its demand for a ``closed shop'' _ a key issue in the talks. Union leaders said a strike could be called any time. Representatives of the guild and the Union-Tribune Publishing Co. met all day Friday without reaching agreement. Company lawyers told guild officials they didn't plan further proposals at this time, setting the stage for a possible strike, which would be the first in the 51 years the guild has represented employees at the two newspapers. Pay is less an issue than disputes over the length of the contract and preservation of a union shop. The company's last proposal called for a one-year pact with salary hikes of 8 percent to 10 percent, said Herb Klein, editor in chief of the Copley Newspapers, a 13-paper chain that includes those involved in the dispute. The guild sought a three-year contract with a 10 percent pay hike the first year and 5 percent raises in the second and third years. The labor team sought guild security under which everyone in guild-covered positions would pay dues whether they are members or not, said George Flynn, chairman of the guild's bargaining committee. The company wants an ``open shop'' that would allow individual workers to decide whether they want to join a union. The guild represents about 1,150 employees in the editorial, photography, circulation, advertising, business, maintenance, telephone communications and library departments. The old contract expired in June 1988.
